abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Avian Influenza Control
            and Human Influenza Emergency Preparedness and Control
            Project for Haiti were as follows: overall outcome was
            moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, and both the Bank and the Borrower performance
            were moderately unsatisfactory. The following are among the
            more important project lessons: (1) Close coordination and
            cooperation between animal health and human health are key
            to successful implementation of investments. (2) The
            establishment of a medium to long-term prevention and
            control program is required. The lesson for this project and
            other animal health interventions is that even if responding
            to a disease specific emergency, interventions also need to
            focus on systemic improvements and basic capacity building
            which are sustainable in the medium to long term. (3)
            Mitigation measures to close a financing gap should be part
            of appraisal. (4) Institutional strengthening in project
            management is the pillar to success in fragile contexts, in
            particular for emergency operations. (5) A flexible and
            timely response is critical.
